column2: Nur Mahomed's old mother lived for a long time in her 'son's' palace, and died in peace.
column3: Nur Mahomed's old mother lived for a long time in her 'son's' palace, and died in peace.

column2: The princess, his wife, although she had got her husband by a trick, found that she could not trick HIM, and so she never tried, but busied herself in teaching her children and scolding her maids.
column3: The princess, his wife, although she had got her husband by a trick, found that she could not trick HIM, and so she never tried, but busied herself in teaching her children and scolding her maids.

column2: As for the old hermit, no trace of him was ever discovered; but the cave is there, and the leaves lie thick in front of it unto this day.
column3: As for the old hermit, no trace of him was ever discovered; but the cave is there, and the leaves lie thick in front of it unto this day.

column2: Story of Wali Dad the Simple-Hearted
column3: Story of Wali Dad the Simple Hearted

column2: Once upon a time there lived a poor old man whose name was Wali Dad Gunjay, or Wali Dad the Bald.
column3: Once upon a time there lived a poor old man whose name was Wali Dad Gunjay, or Wali Dad the Bald.

column2: He had no relations, but lived all by himself in a little mud hut some distance from any town, and made his living by cutting grass in the jungle, and selling it as fodder for horses.
column3: He had no relations, but lived all by himself in a little mud hut some distance from any town, and made his living by cutting grass in the jungle, and selling it as fodder for horses.

column2: He only earned by this five halfpence a day; but he was a simple old man, and needed so little out of it, that he saved up one halfpenny daily, and spent the rest upon such food and clothing as he required.
column3: He only earned by this five halfpence a day; but he was a simple old man, and needed so little out of it, that he saved up one halfpenny daily, and spent the rest upon such food and clothing as he required.

column2: In this way he lived for many years until, one night, he thought that he would count the money he had hidden away in the great earthen pot under the floor of his hut.
column3: In this way he lived for many years until, one night, he thought that he would count the money he had hidden away in the great earthen pot under the floor of his hut.

column2: So he set to work, and with much trouble he pulled the bag out on to the floor, and sat gazing in astonishment at the heap of coins which tumbled out of it.
column3: So he set to work, and with much trouble he pulled the bag out on to the floor, and sat gazing in astonishment at the heap of coins which tumbled out of it.

column2: What should he do with them all?
column3: What should he do with them all?

column2: he wondered.
column3: he wondered.

column2: But he never thought of spending the money on himself, because he was content to pass the rest of his days as he had been doing for ever so long, and he really had no desire for any greater comfort or luxury.
column3: But he never thought of spending the money on himself, because he was content to pass the rest of his days as he had been doing for ever so long, and he really had no desire for any greater comfort or luxury.

column2: At last he threw all the money into an old sack, which he pushed under his bead, and then, rolled in his ragged old blanket, he went off to sleep.
column3: At last he threw all the money into an old sack, which he pushed under his bead, and then, rolled in his ragged old blanket, he went off to sleep.

column2: Early next morning he staggered off with his sack of money to the shop of a jeweller, whom he knew in the town, and bargained with him for a beautiful little gold bracelet.
column3: Early next morning he staggered off with his sack of money to the shop of a jeweller, whom he knew in the town, and bargained with him for a beautiful little gold bracelet.

column2: With this carefully wrapped up in his cotton waistband he went to the house of a rich friend, who was a travelling merchant, and used to wander about with his camels and merchandise through many countries.
column3: With this carefully wrapped up in his cotton waistband he went to the house of a rich friend, who was a travelling merchant, and used to wander about with his camels and merchandise through many countries.

column2: Wali Dad was lucky enough to find him at home, so he sat down, and after a little talk he asked the merchant who was the most virtuous and beautiful lady he had ever met with.
column3: Wali Dad was lucky enough to find him at home, so he sat down, and after a little talk he asked the merchant who was the most virtuous and beautiful lady he had ever met with.

column2: The merchant replied that the princess of Khaistan was renowned everywhere as well for the beauty of her person as for the kindness and generosity of her disposition.
column3: The merchant replied that the princess of Khaistan was renowned everywhere as well for the beauty of her person as for the kindness and generosity of her disposition.

column2: 'Then,' said Wali Dad, 'next time you go that way, give her this little bracelet, with the respectful compliments of one who admires virtue far more than he desires wealth.'
column3: 'Then,' said Wali Dad, 'next time you go that way, give her this little bracelet, with the respectful compliments of one who admires virtue far more than he desires wealth.'

column2: With that he pulled the bracelet from his waistband, and handed it to his friend.
column3: With that he pulled the bracelet from his waistband, and handed it to his friend.

column2: The merchant was naturally much astonished, but said nothing, and made no objection to carrying out his friend's plan.
column3: The merchant was naturally much astonished, but said nothing, and made no objection to carrying out his friend's plan.

column2: Time passed by, and at length the merchant arrived in the course of his travels at the capital of Khaistan.
column3: Time passed by, and at length the merchant arrived in the course of his travels at the capital of Khaistan.

column2: As soon as he had opportunity he presented himself at the palace, and sent in the bracelet, neatly packed in a little perfumed box provided by himself, giving at the same time the message entrusted to him by Wali Dad.
column3: As soon as he had opportunity he presented himself at the palace, and sent in the bracelet, neatly packed in a little perfumed box provided by himself, giving at the same time the message entrusted to him by Wali Dad.

column2: The princess could not think who could have bestowed this present on her, but she bade her servant to tell the merchant that if he would return, after he had finished his business in the city, she would give him her reply.
column3: The princess could not think who could have bestowed this present on her, but she bade her servant to tell the merchant that if he would return, after he had finished his business in the city, she would give him her reply.

column2: In a few days, therefore, the merchant came back, and received from the princess a return present in the shape of a camel-load or rich silks, besides a present of money for himself.
column3: In a few days, therefore, the merchant came back, and received from the princess a return present in the shape of a camel load or rich silks, besides a present of money for himself.

column2: With these he set out on his journey.
column3: With these he set out on his journey.

column2: Some months later he got home again from his journeyings, and proceeded to take Wali Dad the princess's present.
column3: Some months later he got home again from his journeyings, and proceeded to take Wali Dad the princess's present.

column2: Great was the perplexity of the good man to find a camel-load of silks tumbled at his door!
column3: Great was the perplexity of the good man to find a camel load of silks tumbled at his door!

column2: What was he to do with these costly things?
column3: What was he to do with these costly things?

column2: But, presently, after much thought, he begged the merchant to consider whether he did not know of some young prince to whom such treasures might be useful.
column3: But, presently, after much thought, he begged the merchant to consider whether he did not know of some young prince to whom such treasures might be useful.

column2: 'Of course,' cried the merchant, greatly amused; 'from Delhi to Baghdad, and from Constantinople to Lucknow, I know them all; and there lives none worthier than the gallant and wealthy young prince of Nekabad.'
column3: 'Of course,' cried the merchant, greatly amused; 'from Delhi to Baghdad, and from Constantinople to Lucknow, I know them all; and there lives none worthier than the gallant and wealthy young prince of Nekabad.'

column2: 'Very well, then, take the silks to him, with the blessing of an old man,' said Wali Dad, much relieved to be rid of them.
column3: 'Very well, then, take the silks to him, with the blessing of an old man,' said Wali Dad, much relieved to be rid of them.

column2: So, the next time that the merchant journeyed that way he carried the silks with him, and in due course arrived at Nekabad, and sought an audience of the prince.
column3: So, the next time that the merchant journeyed that way he carried the silks with him, and in due course arrived at Nekabad, and sought an audience of the prince.

column2: When he was shown into his presence he produced the beautiful gift of silks that Wali Dad had sent, and begged the young man to accept them as a humble tribute to his worth and greatness.
column3: When he was shown into his presence he produced the beautiful gift of silks that Wali Dad had sent, and begged the young man to accept them as a humble tribute to his worth and greatness.

column2: The prince was much touched by the generosity of the giver, and ordered, as a return present, twelve of the finest breed of horses for which his country was famous to be delivered over to the merchant, to whom also, before he took his leave, he gave a munificent reward for his services.
column3: The prince was much touched by the generosity of the giver, and ordered, as a return present, twelve of the finest breed of horses for which his country was famous to be delivered over to the merchant, to whom also, before he took his leave, he gave a munificent reward for his services.

column2: As before, the merchant at last arrived at home; and next day, he set out for Wali Dad's house with the twelve horses.
column3: As before, the merchant at last arrived at home; and next day, he set out for Wali Dad's house with the twelve horses.

column2: When the old man saw them coming in the distance he said to himself: 'Here's luck! a troop of horses coming!
column3: When the old man saw them coming in the distance he said to himself: 'Here's luck! a troop of horses coming!

column2: They are sure to want quantities of grass, and I shall sell all I have without having to drag it to market.' Thereupon he rushed off and cut grass as fast he could.
column3: They are sure to want quantities of grass, and I shall sell all I have without having to drag it to market.' Thereupon he rushed off and cut grass as fast he could.

column2: When he got back, with as much grass as he could possibly carry, he was greatly discomfited to find that the horses were all for himself.
column3: When he got back, with as much grass as he could possibly carry, he was greatly discomfited to find that the horses were all for himself.

column2: At first he could not think what to do with them, but, after a little, a brilliant idea struck him! He gave two to the merchant, and begged him to take the rest to the princess of Khaistan, who was clearly the fittest person to possess such beautiful animals.
column3: At first he could not think what to do with them, but, after a little, a brilliant idea struck him! He gave two to the merchant, and begged him to take the rest to the princess of Khaistan, who was clearly the fittest person to possess such beautiful animals.

column2: The merchant departed, laughing.

column2: But, true to his old friend's request, he took the horses with him on his next journey, and eventually presented them safely to the princess.
column3: But, true to his old friend's request, he took the horses with him on his next journey, and eventually presented them safely to the princess.

column2: This time the princess sent for the merchant, and questioned him about the giver.
column3: This time the princess sent for the merchant, and questioned him about the giver.

column2: Now, the merchant was usually a most honest man, but he did not quite like to describe Wali Dad in his true light as an old man whose income was five halfpence a day, and who had hardly clothes to cover him.
column3: Now, the merchant was usually a most honest man, but he did not quite like to describe Wali Dad in his true light as an old man whose income was five halfpence a day, and who had hardly clothes to cover him.

column2: So he told her that his friend had heard stories of her beauty and goodness, and had longed to lay the best he had at her feet.
column3: So he told her that his friend had heard stories of her beauty and goodness, and had longed to lay the best he had at her feet.

column2: The princess then took her father into her confidence, and begged him to advise her what courtesy she might return to one who persisted in making her such presents.
column3: The princess then took her father into her confidence, and begged him to advise her what courtesy she might return to one who persisted in making her such presents.

column2: 'Well,' said the king, 'you cannot refuse them; so the best thing you can do is to send this unknown friend at once a present so magnificent that he is not likely to be able to send you anything better, and so will be ashamed to send anything at all!' Then he ordered that, in place of each of the ten horses, two mules laden with silver should be returned by her.

column2: Thus, in a few hours, the merchant found himself in charge of a splendid caravan; and he had to hire a number of armed men to defend it on the road against the robbers, and he was glad indeed to find himself back again in Wali Dad's hut.

column2: 'Well, now,' cried Wali Dad, as he viewed all the wealth laid at his door, 'I can well repay that kind prince for his magnificent present of horses; but to be sure you have been put to great expenses!
column3: 'Well, now,' cried Wali Dad, as he viewed all the wealth laid at his door, 'I can well repay that kind prince for his magnificent present of horses; but to be sure you have been put to great expenses!

column3: Still, if you will accept six mules and their loads, and will take the rest straight to Nekabad, I shall thank you heartily.'

column2: The merchant felt handsomely repaid for his trouble, and wondered greatly how the matter would turn out.
column3: The merchant felt handsomely repaid for his trouble, and wondered greatly how the matter would turn out.

column2: So he made no difficulty about it; and as soon as he could get things ready, he set out for Nekabad with this new and princely gift.

column2: This time the prince, too, was embarrassed, and questioned the merchant closely.
column3: This time the prince, too, was embarrassed, and questioned the merchant closely.

column2: The merchant felt that his credit was at stake, and whilst inwardly determining that he would not carry the joke any further, could not help describing Wali Dad in such glowing terms that the old man would never have known himself had he heard them.
column3: The merchant felt that his credit was at stake, and whilst inwardly determining that he would not carry the joke any further, could not help describing Wali Dad in such glowing terms that the old man would never have known himself had he heard them.

column2: The prince, like the king of Khaistan, determined that he would send in return a gift that would be truly royal, and which would perhaps prevent the unknown giver sending him anything more.
column3: The prince, like the king of Khaistan, determined that he would send in return a gift that would be truly royal, and which would perhaps prevent the unknown giver sending him anything more.

column3: So he made up a caravan on twenty splendid horses caparisoned in gold embroidered cloths, with fine morocco saddles and silver bridles and stirrups, also twenty camels of the best breed, which had the speed of race horses, and could swing along at a trot all day without getting tired; and, lastly, twenty elephants, with magnificent silver howdahs and coverings of silk embroidered with pearls.

column3: To take care of these animals the merchant hired a little army of men; and the troop made a great show as they travelled along.

column3: When Wali Dad from a distance saw the cloud of dust which the caravan made, and the glitter of its appointments, he said to himself: 'By Allah! here's a grand crowd coming!

column2: Grass will be selling well to-day!' And with that he hurried off to the jungle and cut grass as fast as he could.

column3: As soon as he got back he found the caravan had stopped at his door, and the merchant was waiting, a little anxiously, to tell him the news and to congratulate him upon his riches.

column3: Do you take for yourself two horses, two camels, and two elephants, with all their trappings, and present the rest to her.'

column2: The merchant at first objected to these remarks, and pointed out to Wali Dad that he was beginning to feel these embassies a little awkward.
column3: The merchant at first objected to these remarks, and pointed out to Wali Dad that he was beginning to feel these embassies a little awkward.

column2: Of course he was himself richly repaid, so far as expenses went; but still he did not like going so often, and he was getting nervous.
column3: Of course he was himself richly repaid, so far as expenses went; but still he did not like going so often, and he was getting nervous.

column2: At length, however he consented to go once more, but he promised himself never to embark on another such enterprise.
column3: At length, however he consented to go once more, but he promised himself never to embark on another such enterprise.

column3: So, after a few days' rest, the caravan started off once more for Khaistan.

column2: The moment the king of Khaistan saw the gorgeous train of men and beasts entering his palace courtyard, he was so amazed that he hurried down in person to inquire about it, and became dumb when he heard that these also were a present from the princely Wali Dad, and were for the princess, his daughter.
column3: The moment the king of Khaistan saw the gorgeous train of men and beasts entering his palace courtyard, he was so amazed that he hurried down in person to inquire about it, and became dumb when he heard that these also were a present from the princely Wali Dad, and were for the princess, his daughter.

column2: He went hastily off to her apartments, and said to her: 'I tell you what it is, my dear, this man wants to marry you; that is the meaning of all these presents!
column3: He went hastily off to her apartments, and said to her: 'I tell you what it is, my dear, this man wants to marry you; that is the meaning of all these presents!

column2: There is nothing for it but that we go and pay him a visit in person.
column3: There is nothing for it but that we go and pay him a visit in person.

column2: He must be a man of immense wealth, and as he is so devoted to you, perhaps you might do worse than marry him!'
column3: He must be a man of immense wealth, and as he is so devoted to you, perhaps you might do worse than marry him!'

column2: The merchant, the king declared, was to guide the party.

column2: The feelings of the poor merchant in this sore dilemma can hardly be imagined.
column3: The feelings of the poor merchant in this sore dilemma can hardly be imagined.

column2: Willingly would he have run away; but he was treated with so much hospitality as Wali Dad's representative, that he hardly got an instant's real peace, and never any opportunity of slipping away.
column3: Willingly would he have run away; but he was treated with so much hospitality as Wali Dad's representative, that he hardly got an instant's real peace, and never any opportunity of slipping away.

column2: On the seventh day they all started, amidst thunderous salutes from the ramparts of the city, and much dust, and cheering, and blaring of trumpets.

column2: Day after day they moved on, and every day the poor merchant felt more ill and miserable.
column3: Day after day they moved on, and every day the poor merchant felt more ill and miserable.

column2: He wondered what kind of death the king would invent for him, and went through almost as much torture, as he lay awake nearly the whole of every night thinking over the situation, as he would have suffered if the king's executioners were already setting to work upon his neck.

column2: At last they were only one day's march from Wali Dad's little mud home. Here a great encampment was made, and the merchant was sent on to tell Wali Dad that the King and Princess of Khaistan had arrived and were seeking an interview.

column2: When the merchant arrived he found the poor old man eating his evening meal of onions and dry bread, and when he told him of all that had happened he had not the heart to proceed to load him with the reproaches which rose to his tongue.
column3: When the merchant arrived he found the poor old man eating his evening meal of onions and dry bread, and when he told him of all that had happened he had not the heart to proceed to load him with the reproaches which rose to his tongue.

column2: For Wali Dad was overwhelmed with grief and shame for himself, for his friend, and for the name and honour of the princess; and he wept and plucked at his beard, and groaned most piteously.
column3: For Wali Dad was overwhelmed with grief and shame for himself, for his friend, and for the name and honour of the princess; and he wept and plucked at his beard, and groaned most piteously.

column2: With tears he begged the merchant to detain them for one day by any kind of excuse he could think of, and to come in the morning to discuss what they should do.
column3: With tears he begged the merchant to detain them for one day by any kind of excuse he could think of, and to come in the morning to discuss what they should do.

column2: As soon as the merchant was gone Wali Dad made up his mind that there was only one honourable way out of the shame and distress that he had created by his foolishness, and that was--to kill himself.
column3: As soon as the merchant was gone Wali Dad made up his mind that there was only one honourable way out of the shame and distress that he had created by his foolishness, and that was-to kill himself.

column2: So, without stopping to ask any one's advice, he went off in the middle of the night to a place where the river wound along at the base of steep rocky cliffs of great height, and determined to throw himself down and put an end to his life.
column3: So, without stopping to ask any one's advice, he went off in the middle of the night to a place where the river wound along at the base of steep rocky cliffs of great height, and determined to throw himself down and put an end to his life.

column2: When he got to the place he drew back a few paces, took a little run, and at the very edge of that dreadful black gulf he stopped short!
column3: When he got to the place he drew back a few paces, took a little run, and at the very edge of that dreadful black gulf he stopped short!

column2: He COULD not do it!
column3: He COULD not do it!

column2: From below, unseen in the blackness of the deep night shadows, the water roared and boiled round the jagged rocks--he could picture the place as he knew it, only ten times more pitiless and forbidding in the visionless darkness; the wind soughed through the gorge with fearsome sighs, and rustlings and whisperings, and the bushes and grasses that grew in the ledges of the cliffs seemed to him like living creatures that danced and beckoned, shadowy and indistinct.
column3: From below, unseen in the blackness of the deep night shadows, the water roared and boiled round the jagged rocks-he could picture the place as he knew it, only ten times more pitiless and forbidding in the visionless darkness; the wind soughed through the gorge with fearsome sighs, and rustlings and whisperings, and the bushes and grasses that grew in the ledges of the cliffs seemed to him like living creatures that danced and beckoned, shadowy and indistinct.

column2: An owl laughed 'Hoo! hoo!' almost in his face, as he peered over the edge of the gulf, and the old man threw himself back in a perspiration of horror.
column3: An owl laughed 'Hoo! hoo!' almost in his face, as he peered over the edge of the gulf, and the old man threw himself back in a perspiration of horror.

column2: He was afraid!
column3: He was afraid!

column2: He drew back shuddering, and covering his face in his hands he wept aloud.
column3: He drew back shuddering, and covering his face in his hands he wept aloud.

column2: Presently he was aware of a gentle radiance that shed itself before him. Surely morning was not already coming to hasten and reveal his disgrace! column3: Presently he was aware of a gentle radiance that shed itself before him. Surely morning was not already coming to hasten and reveal his disgrace! column3: 'Why do you weep, old man?' said one, in a voice as clear and musical as that of the bulbul.

column2: 'I weep for shame,' replied he.

column2: 'What do you here?' questioned the other.

column3: His old cotton rags of clothes were changed to beautiful linen and embroidered cloth; on his hard, bare feet were warm, soft shoes, and on his head a great jewelled turban.

column2: And up an avenue of giant place trees the peris led him, dumb with amazement.
column3: And up an avenue of giant place trees the peris led him, dumb with amazement.

column2: At the end of the avenue, on the very spot where his hut had stood, a gorgeous palace appeared, ablaze with myriads of lights.
column3: At the end of the avenue, on the very spot where his hut had stood, a gorgeous palace appeared, ablaze with myriads of lights.

column2: Its great porticoes and verandahs were occupied by hurrying servants, and guards paced to and fro and saluted him respectfully as he drew near, along mossy walks and through sweeping grassy lawns where fountains were playing and flowers scented the air. Wali Dad stood stunned and helpless.
column3: Its great porticoes and verandahs were occupied by hurrying servants, and guards paced to and fro and saluted him respectfully as he drew near, along mossy walks and through sweeping grassy lawns where fountains were playing and flowers scented the air. Wali Dad stood stunned and helpless.

column2: 'Fear not,' said one of the peris; 'go to your house, and learn that God rewards the simple-hearted.'
column3: 'Fear not,' said one of the peris; 'go to your house, and learn that God rewards the simple hearted.'

column2: With these words they both disappeared and left him.
column3: With these words they both disappeared and left him.

column2: He walked on, thinking still that he must be dreaming.
column3: He walked on, thinking still that he must be dreaming.

column2: Very soon he retired to rest in a splendid room, far grander than anything he had ever dreamed of.
column3: Very soon he retired to rest in a splendid room, far grander than anything he had ever dreamed of.

column2: When morning dawned he woke, and found that the palace, and himself, and his servants were all real, and that he was not dreaming after all!
column3: When morning dawned he woke, and found that the palace, and himself, and his servants were all real, and that he was not dreaming after all!

column2: If he was dumbfounded, the merchant, who was ushered into his presence soon after sunrise, was much more so.
column3: If he was dumbfounded, the merchant, who was ushered into his presence soon after sunrise, was much more so.

column2: He told Wali Dad that he had not slept all night, and by the first streak of daylight had started to seek out his friend.
column3: He told Wali Dad that he had not slept all night, and by the first streak of daylight had started to seek out his friend.

column2: And what a search he had had!
column3: And what a search he had had!

column2: A great stretch of wild jungle country had, in the night, been changed into parks and gardens; and if it had not been for some of Wali Dad's new servants, who found him and brought him to the palace, he would have fled away under the impression that his trouble had sent him crazy, and that all he saw was only imagination.
column3: A great stretch of wild jungle country had, in the night, been changed into parks and gardens; and if it had not been for some of Wali Dad's new servants, who found him and brought him to the palace, he would have fled away under the impression that his trouble had sent him crazy, and that all he saw was only imagination.

column2: Then Wali Dad told the merchant all that had happened.
column3: Then Wali Dad told the merchant all that had happened.

column2: By his advice he sent an invitation to the king and princess of Khaistan to come and be his guests, together with all their retinue and servants, down to the very humblest in the camp.
column3: By his advice he sent an invitation to the king and princess of Khaistan to come and be his guests, together with all their retinue and servants, down to the very humblest in the camp.

column2: For three nights and days a great feast was held in honour of the royal guests.
column3: For three nights and days a great feast was held in honour of the royal guests.

column2: Every evening the king and his nobles were served on golden plates and from golden cups; and the smaller people on silver plates and from silver cups; and each evening each guest was requested to keep the places and cups that they had used as a remembrance of the occasion. Never had anything so splendid been seen.
column3: Every evening the king and his nobles were served on golden plates and from golden cups; and the smaller people on silver plates and from silver cups; and each evening each guest was requested to keep the places and cups that they had used as a remembrance of the occasion. Never had anything so splendid been seen.

column2: Besides the great dinners, there were sports and hunting, and dances, and amusements of all sorts.
column3: Besides the great dinners, there were sports and hunting, and dances, and amusements of all sorts.

column2: On the fourth day the king of Khaistan took his host aside, and asked him whether it was true, as he had suspected, that he wished to marry his daughter.
column3: On the fourth day the king of Khaistan took his host aside, and asked him whether it was true, as he had suspected, that he wished to marry his daughter.

column2: But Wali Dad, after thanking him very much for the compliment, said that he had never dreamed of so great an honour, and that he was far too old and ugly for so fair a lady; but he begged the king to stay with him until he could send for the Prince of Nekabad, who was a most excellent, brave, and honourable young man, and would surely be delighted to try to win the hand of the beautiful princess.
column3: But Wali Dad, after thanking him very much for the compliment, said that he had never dreamed of so great an honour, and that he was far too old and ugly for so fair a lady; but he begged the king to stay with him until he could send for the Prince of Nekabad, who was a most excellent, brave, and honourable young man, and would surely be delighted to try to win the hand of the beautiful princess.

column2: To this the king agreed, and Wali Dad sent the merchant to Nekabad, with a number of attendants, and with such handsome presents that the prince came at once, fell head over ears in love with the princess, and married her at Wali Dad's palace amidst a fresh outburst of rejoicings.
column3: To this the king agreed, and Wali Dad sent the merchant to Nekabad, with a number of attendants, and with such handsome presents that the prince came at once, fell head over ears in love with the princess, and married her at Wali Dad's palace amidst a fresh outburst of rejoicings.

column2: And now the King of Khaistan and the Prince and Princess of Nekabad, each went back to their own country; and Wali Dad lived to a good old age, befriending all who were in trouble and preserving, in his prosperity, the simple-hearted and generous nature that he had when he was only Wali Dad Gunjay, the grass cutter.
column3: And now the King of Khaistan and the Prince and Princess of Nekabad, each went back to their own country; and Wali Dad lived to a good old age, befriending all who were in trouble and preserving, in his prosperity, the simple hearted and generous nature that he had when he was only Wali Dad Gunjay, the grass cutter.
